trans-unit.source: Use Power BI with SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Power BI with SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for using Power BI with Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for using Power BI with Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: Use Power BI with SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Use Power BI with SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: As with Azure SQL Database, SQL Data Warehouse Direct Connect allows user to leverage powerful logical pushdown alongside the analytical capabilities of Power BI.
trans-unit.target: As with Azure SQL Database, SQL Data Warehouse Direct Connect allows user to leverage powerful logical pushdown alongside the analytical capabilities of Power BI.

trans-unit.source: With Direct Connect, queries are sent back to your Azure SQL Data Warehouse in real time as you explore the data.
trans-unit.target: With Direct Connect, queries are sent back to your Azure SQL Data Warehouse in real time as you explore the data.

trans-unit.source: This, combined with the scale of SQL Data Warehouse, enables users to create dynamic reports in minutes against terabytes of data.
trans-unit.target: This, combined with the scale of SQL Data Warehouse, enables users to create dynamic reports in minutes against terabytes of data.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the introduction of the Open in Power BI button allows users to directly connect Power BI to their SQL Data Warehouse without collecting information from other parts of Azure.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the introduction of the Open in Power BI button allows users to directly connect Power BI to their SQL Data Warehouse without collecting information from other parts of Azure.

trans-unit.source: When using Direct Connect please note:
trans-unit.target: When using Direct Connect please note:

trans-unit.source: Specify the fully qualified server name when connecting (see below for more details)
trans-unit.target: Specify the fully qualified server name when connecting (see below for more details)

trans-unit.source: Ensure firewall rules for the database are configured to "Allow access to Azure services".
trans-unit.target: Ensure firewall rules for the database are configured to "Allow access to Azure services".

trans-unit.source: Every action such as selecting a column or adding a filter will directly query the data warehouse
trans-unit.target: Every action such as selecting a column or adding a filter will directly query the data warehouse

trans-unit.source: Tiles are refreshed approximately every 15 minutes (refresh does not need to be scheduled)
trans-unit.target: Tiles are refreshed approximately every 15 minutes (refresh does not need to be scheduled)

trans-unit.source: Q&A is not available for Direct Connect datasets
trans-unit.target: Q&A is not available for Direct Connect datasets

trans-unit.source: Schema changes are not picked up automatically
trans-unit.target: Schema changes are not picked up automatically

trans-unit.source: These restrictions and notes may change as we continue to improve the experiences.
trans-unit.target: These restrictions and notes may change as we continue to improve the experiences.

trans-unit.source: The steps to connect are detailed below.
trans-unit.target: The steps to connect are detailed below.

trans-unit.source: Using the ‘Open in Power BI’ button
trans-unit.target: Using the ‘Open in Power BI’ button

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to move between your SQL Data Warehouse and Power BI is with the Open in Power BI button.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to move between your SQL Data Warehouse and Power BI is with the Open in Power BI button.

trans-unit.source: This button allows you to seamlessly begin creating new dashboards in Power BI.
trans-unit.target: This button allows you to seamlessly begin creating new dashboards in Power BI.

trans-unit.source: To get started navigate to your SQL Data Warehouse instance in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: To get started navigate to your SQL Data Warehouse instance in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click the Open in Power BI button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Open in Power BI button.

trans-unit.source: If we are not able to sign you in directly, or if you do not have a Power BI account, you will need to sign-in.
trans-unit.target: If we are not able to sign you in directly, or if you do not have a Power BI account, you will need to sign-in.

trans-unit.source: You will be directed to the SQL Data Warehouse connection page, with the information from your SQL Data Warehouse pre-populated.
trans-unit.target: You will be directed to the SQL Data Warehouse connection page, with the information from your SQL Data Warehouse pre-populated.

trans-unit.source: After entering your credentials you will be fully conected to your SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: After entering your credentials you will be fully conected to your SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: Connecting through the Power BI portal
trans-unit.target: Connecting through the Power BI portal

trans-unit.source: In addition to using the Open in Power BI button, users can also connect to their SQL Data Warehouse through the Power BI Portal.
trans-unit.target: In addition to using the Open in Power BI button, users can also connect to their SQL Data Warehouse through the Power BI Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Get Data at the bottom of the navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: Click Get Data at the bottom of the navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: Select Big Data & More.
trans-unit.target: Select Big Data & More.

trans-unit.source: Once on the Big Data & More page, select the SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Once on the Big Data & More page, select the SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: Enter the necessary connection information.
trans-unit.target: Enter the necessary connection information.

trans-unit.source: The in the Finding Parameters section below shows where this data can be found.
trans-unit.target: The in the Finding Parameters section below shows where this data can be found.

trans-unit.source: Drilling into the dataset, you can explore all of the tables and columns in your database.
trans-unit.target: Drilling into the dataset, you can explore all of the tables and columns in your database.

trans-unit.source: Selecting a column will send a query back to the source, dynamically creating your visual.
trans-unit.target: Selecting a column will send a query back to the source, dynamically creating your visual.

trans-unit.source: These visuals can be saved in a new report, and pinned back to your dashboard.
trans-unit.target: These visuals can be saved in a new report, and pinned back to your dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Finding parameter values
trans-unit.target: Finding parameter values

trans-unit.source: Your fully qualified server name and database name can be found in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Your fully qualified server name and database name can be found in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Please note that SQL Data Warehouse only has a presence in the Azure Preview portal at this time.
trans-unit.target: Please note that SQL Data Warehouse only has a presence in the Azure Preview portal at this time.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For an overview of integration, see [SQL Data Warehouse integration overview][].
trans-unit.target: For an overview of integration, see [SQL Data Warehouse integration overview][].

trans-unit.source: For more development tips, see [SQL Data Warehouse development overview][].
trans-unit.target: For more development tips, see [SQL Data Warehouse development overview][].
